For those who want to know; is Slender Man a good horror film, the basic answer is...not really. For the longer answer, let's strap ourselves in and analyze this mess. Going into this film, I had heard multiple stories; none of them good. I'm not going to focus on the film's tastelessness in bringing to life an internet legend that resulted in a disturbingly horrific crime. By the time this film premiered, the Slender Man craze had come and gone, and despite there been so much material for this film to use, it is really quite two-dimensional.

To the film's credit, there are some genuinely creepy scenes that do create a sense of dread, with great use of imagery occasionally used. The functional original score does add to the sustained threat, the drum beat used when Slender Man is near being especially effective, though even the soundtrack can't save the film, with some of the 'scary' devices shamelessly repeated, causing the effect to be significantly reduced. As the film progresses, it begins taking cliché horror tropes from better known franchises, in particular, The Ring, including a cursed video and a girl in desperate need of a hair-cut. If parroting classics wasn't enough, there are sequences of trippy hallucinations, in which POV shots that incorporate Hitchcock's dolly-zoom technique are used, alongside bizarre transitional effects that make little sense. During one 'horror' moment I burst out laughing, and unless Slender Man is secretly a parody, this represents a failure on the filmmaker's part.

What doesn't help the horror are the film's characters. Two issues; first, I would be hard-pressed to describe any of them, considering the significant lack of characterization. Second, the main character is boring. Stereotypically in horror films, the protagonist tries to warn a group of rational-minded individuals who refuse to accept the truth, of the supernatural threat. This movie however, probably thinking it was being intelligent, flips this on its head, whereby the lead character is the one with their head in the sand. Hallie (Julia Goldani Telles) is a plank of wood, who isn't particularly likable, for A) her refusal to accept the truth, even when she sees Slender Man watching her, B) the inconsiderate attitude she demonstrates for her friends, being more smitten for a guy than her BFFs, C) her choice to ignore her sister (Taylor Richardson), and D) the idiotic decisions her character makes that put her, and others, at unnecessary risk.

If you knew there was an evil entity in the woods, would you go there? Well, these characters do. Perhaps I should now talk about the 'plot'. Hallie, along with her three friends, Wren (Joey King), Chloe (Jaz Sinclair) and Katie (Annalise Basso), during a sleepover, decide to summon Slender Man, which is as easy as clicking on a link. The three girls are all affected by the 'ritual', eventually leading to one predictably disappearing. There is also Tom (Alex Fitzalan), who is shoehorned in as a potential love-interest, and whose narrative is largely unfulfilled in the five odd minutes he appears in. Besides the contrived nature of the plot, the second biggest issue is that the feature doesn't focus upon Wren, who is the film's most intriguing character, demonstrating a determination to help others, studious investigative skills, and courage; three qualities that the other characters lack.

This is only exacerbated by the utter stupidity of the characters. Their investigation into how to put an end to Slender Man's pursuit leads them to an 'expert' online, who provides strict guidelines that must be followed to the letter. Do you think more than one character decides to do the complete opposite? You would be right. Do you think more than one character does exactly what they were told not to do? Two for two. This makes feeling sympathetic for the characters a challenge, for how can you feel sorry for anyone who lacks total common sense and reasoning?

That said, the film is almost entirely logical...until the 2/3 mark where we get to a hospital sequence. Then it devolves into a contradictory, illogical mess. There is a twist around this part, though it was less a shocker, and more of an 'Oh, that's what's happening, eh?' Over the course of the feature, we occasionally receive glimpses of the world Slender Man inhabits, and in so doing, we can almost imagine the kind of film we could have received. All ghosts are meant to have 'rules' that they abide by, and the lacking complexity surrounding the antagonistic force is disappointing to say the least.

Why is he summoned from the internet? How is he able to affect technology? Why does he wear a fancy three-piece suit? Why doesn't he have a face? How come he occasionally has tentacles? Why does he exclusively target children and teenagers? What is his secret to being so thin? I know the film is based upon an urban legend conceived entirely online, and the audience could do some investigation of their own, but still, refusing to add depth to the film's title villain is just lazy screen-writing.

Slender Man is ultimately...fine, but it doesn't succeed in developing a compelling or thought-provoking narrative. Neither does it effectively create a nightmarish fantasy that will ruin your sleep. You can watch it once, though repeated viewing may potentially damage your intelligence.

It's decent and does not create problems, that made that 3.1 rating up there happen. Acting was also on level, that wasn't the aspect that will make the most cringe. What could make you cringe is the story/plot - in my opinion, this was the easiest, cheapest way to bring slender man mythos to screen - there's way more potential to this. Even bigger problem was the screenplay which simply felt lazy and lousy, as if they went with the first ideas on the whiteboard, not pushing the creative thinking it all. Basically, you've seen the whole formula too many times already. That's pretty much it, the script didn't generate any excitement, mystery or suspense, so it all came out as a flat note, a boring snooze fest. The trailer was better than the movie itself, and that has never been good. Believe an honest horror fan and stay away from this, read the creepypasta again, if you want a slender man vibe again. My rating: 3/10.

Not just to pile on on a low-rated movie, this one's biggest and worst problem is how insufferably boring it is.

With regards to the plot, it feels as if it was written very slowly over a very long period of time, by someone who did not bother to read what they had already written so as to actually keep up with their own ideas.

Things happen and are inexplicably dropped minutes later. One of the main protagonist girls goes missing and a token attempt to find her is made by her friends and the townsfolk. Her father has a rather extreme incident of harassing her friends about where she is. Then inexplicably she's never mentioned by anyone ever again except for the protagonists and only with regards to Slender Man.

An attempt is made to contact Slender Man and "give" him something that they each love. This is never even mentioned by any of them for almost a full half hour afterward.

The amount of fixation with the "celebrity" of Slender Man seems to be overwhelming everything else about the film. We are constantly told about how cunning and dangerous Slender Man is, and how he spreads all throughout the internet with his mythos, but we never see anything like this in the film. Anything involving SLender Man's actions in the film are incoherent and have to be explained after the fact in order for us to realize what is even happening, otherwise it all comes across as a completely random ghostly haunting from the ghost of something that might not even be sentient.

It's only very close to the end that the movie seems to remember that it had a plot once, and scrambles to catch up.

All of the above is enough to crater a movie, but it could've still been a watchable and even fun experience. Unfortunately, the movie is insufferably boring on top of all of it.

review_title: First time that I am this bothered by imdb trolls
review_detailed_main:
Slender Man is not a good movie. It's not utterly bad, but it's far from decent or even entertaining. Is that a problem? Of course not. But if you've seen your share of horror movies, than you can't miss the mistakes in this movie. I'm not talking about plot holes, or goofs, but sloppiness.

The acting isn't even that bad, and the performer who played Slender Man, did a great job. But other than that, this movie relies on annoying characters, terrible motivation and dialogue, borrowing from an existing urban legend, but without adding background or originality, no conclusive (open) ending etc. etc. The biggest sin from this movie is (a) that it simply isn't scary, and (b) that it doesn't even attempt to be original, resulting in everything just falling flat.

Again, is this a huge problem? Of course not. It's a horror movie that you can watch with low expectations. But the amount of people giving this a 1 or 10, while writing a complete nonsensical review, is astonishing. I know this isn't rare nowadays, so it's a pity that many people are (purposely?) raising the wrong expectations.

This really has to be one of the worst movies in the so-called horror genre I've ever watched. In fact, I switched it off after 30 minutes it was so bad! Substandard acting; no development of characters; pathetic and puerile plot; and the list goes on! It is rare I will turn a movie off before the end, but I felt I was just wasting my time trying to endure it. How anyone could suggest they enjoyed this movie is beyond me. If I could rate it 0/10 I would. Sadly, I cannot, so 1/10 will have to suffice.

review_title: One of the better teen horrors with "realistic" teens
review_detailed_main: First off I do not understand the users giving this a 1, unless they truly have never watched any of the tens of thousands micro budget-horrifying acting-no script-horrendous camera work and directing films out there. And it is getting monotonous seeing people write "worst movie ever" repeatedly. So my 10 may be inflated to offset these inexperienced film viewers ( I'd have given this a solid 7, maybe 8). Back to my review... First thing that struck me was this movie actually utilized actors that looked and behaved like real teenagers. Unlike many teen based films where they appear in their 30s and act like immature 20 something year olds. While their are so many variations of the Slender Man legend, including the factual murder case that occured in Wisvonsin in 2014, this film did effectively capture a few of those story lines. The use of shadows, visuals just barely seen and the music were also all very effective. The additional hallucenogenic visuals and that of Slender Man himself were also pretty good, sometimes the CGI was a but too obvious. Overall this movie was able to create an atmospheric, supernatural, myth based teen horror without gratuitous violence or nudity often found in movies attempting to attract a teen fan base.

review_title: Not bad. Not scary. Just meh.
review_detailed_main: I'll admit - I didn't enjoy the movie. Acting wasn't too bad, but I seriously think there's just too much needless screaming. Who am I to judge the acting? I'm not a director. I just feel that when a horror movie relies on so many jump scares, you know the horror just isn't working. I turned off the lights, blasted the sound system and watched the movie alone and yet, I find myself falling asleep. Special effects aren't convincing. And yes, I strongly believe that horror doesn't need to rely on gore. Not at all. I was genuinely terrified by "The Ring" (Japan version). Thai movie "Shutter" sent chills down my back. "Mirrors" made me fear my own reflection for months and these movies relied not on gore but atmospheric tensions and the fear of the unknown to grip viewers in fear. However, all things said, I don't think "Slenderman" deserves such low rating. The horror just didn't work for me.

review_title: Pretty good, personally loved it in spite of flaws
review_detailed_main: I really like this movie, but I know not a lot of people do. Sure, it's more creepy than scary, but that really did well for me with the subject matter. Though very isolated from his CreepyPasta lore, this movie acts as a really well done incarnation to bring this character to the minds of people who may not know that CreepyPasta lore. I know there are other incarnations of this particular creature/character, but this movie was phenomenal in my opinion. Not big studio, huge budget phenomenal, but phenomenal in the way that 28Days is. Lower budget than some big name horror movies but definitely put to good use.

Decent watch at best, probably won't watch again, and can't really recommend.

I'm a big fan of Joey King, but she wasn't really in a positive to save the movie.

The production value is obviously there, the effects are even good, and there are several intense moments that should set the atmosphere, but I just couldn't bring myself to care.

The writing has to be to blame. It's 4-5 shallow, empty characters with just enough flavor to tell them apart, and I just can't care about them.

The movie focuses on the subtly of it all, the growing madness that Slender Man instills in his victims without properly building the tension or showing the characters slowly losing it, which would have given good actors the ability to save it. Instead they use a lot of "it happened offscreen" or sudden cuts to show a lose of time, and we get a character suddenly looking confused instead of taking the audience on a journey with the character.

Maybe it's not the writing, and maybe the editor just didn't know what they were doing? "What are all these long dramatic series in here? This is so boring! *cut* Eh, they'll get the point."

With all the options out there, I just don't think this is worth your time. I could tell you to just watch the 3rd act, and you'd probably get as much out of this movie as you're going to get from the beginning.

I'm expecting this to be rubbish. I quite fancied it when I first heard about it and saw a few stills, but reports are not good. We're in small suburban 'get me out of this town' America... again. These things are always set in exactly the same place aren't they. This one see's us join a group of 4 high school girls. They're bored. At a sleepover the subject of Slender Man comes up. An internet lore about a tall bloke with long arms that takes children to another place. The film's source is a muddy story, born via the internet in the early naughties. A narrative comprising different directions and ideas from a multitude of creators, no one really taking ownership. A creature designed by committee. This fundamentally is the problem with Slender Man now brought to the cinema screen. The girls watch a video on how to summon him, it's predictably spooky graphic nonsense. Some chiming bells, pagan symbols etc. Nothing happens... or does it. Wren (Joey King) is having nightmares and Katie (Annalise Basso) is oddly drawn to creaking trees in graveyards. Then Katie goes missing. It's all fairly standard stuff, largely at night, where figures are hidden in the shadows. Forests with tall trees and flashlights. Eerie music and nocturnal wildlife. Teenage occult dabblings. There's too much instant belief in the myth from the three remaining girls for this to have any bite, but I guess you have to except the tropes and hope for the best. It's biggest problem is it's reliance on jump scares, not to mention lack of substance. It's a nice simple short story at best, that even at 90 minutes feels like it's struggling to hold any interest. I'm fine with a silly suspense thriller. I don't need gore, amazing FX, not this has those, but I need a solid story and a plot that's engaging. This essentially is a bit of dull preamble, followed by a flatline hour of the three girls being stalked by Slender Man whilst they try to retrieve Katie from his clutches. One by one they're picked off, there's no ebb and flow it's just a slow creep or plod toward the end. I'll admit I do like the Slender Man design, he's a simple and elegant monster, but aesthetics alone cannot carry a film. The reports were right.

review_title: Oh my God, they killed the myth of Slender Man with a film
review_detailed_main:
What started off as an internet urban legend has finally been committed to the silver screen, unfortunately it's been packaged up in a way that, according to reviews, isn't to everybody's liking. From my point of view, I have to agree with the reviews I've seen too - which is a pity as this could have been a great horror film.

In short, a group of school friends attempt to disprove the existence of Slender Man, by beckoning him. When one of the friends goes missing, it becomes apparent that they were wrong in disbelief.

The story has been told before, albeit with different characters bringing the scares. The way the plot unfolds, has also been done before, in some instances in the other stories I'm thinking about in that last sentence. The film actually felt like a 'lift and shift' from about 50 other movies I could name. Despite having an occasionally dumb script, the cast seem to do their best - thankfully they have to scream a few times and that detracts from the script. This film may actually go on to become the reason why the internet urban legend is killed and forgotten - pity. The 3 out of 10 I'm giving this is kind.

Seriously, how can you take a creepy character and make it look dumb and ridiculous? This movie takes the goddamn cake.

I can't believe I spent over an hour of my life watching this boring piece of crap. The acting didn't bother me but the script? Are you serious? Who thought it would be a great idea to take a cool legend and straight out make it cringey?

Just don't waste your time. Please.

review_title: Terrible characters, boring plot, and no suspense at all.
review_detailed_main:
Slender Man (2 out of 5 stars).

Slender Man had potential in actually being a creepy scary film. A tall, faceless, and long arms mysterious being does sound creepy when it is lurking in the forests, stalking people. The film fails to even being a scary movie. It has everything that fails in its cliché of horror movies. Stupid teens, boring direction that lacks scares and consistent scenes. Lets not forget the plot does feel more like a rip off from The Ring movies.

The characters are all bad and lacking in characteristics that you would root for. These teens made the stupid decision to watch a video of a slender man on a website. From there, Slender man is stalking these teens one by one. Luring them into the forest or traumatizing them to the part they go insane. Teens make the stupid decision and it is difficult to even care for them. Also, if it is a plot hole or something. But where are all there parents. They go walking around their homes on a school night, yelling and screaming cause something is coming inside their homes. And no adult supervision is found. Until, one of the kids ends up in a hospital and the parents finally show up out of nowhere. The direction is lacking comprehensive with its storytelling. Characters go missing when one of the girls is trying to reach her boyfriend. You really do not hear back about what happened to him.

The acting is dull. Joey King, Julia Goldani Telles, Jaz Sinclair, and Annalise Basso were all tedious with their performance. The script also was lacking in characteristics with their characters. Which made it hard for you to even care for them.

The plot was similar to The Ring. Except, they are being stalked by a mysterious tall, skinny, faceless man. It does have some creepy moments. But it fails with its cliché horror storytelling. And the climax and third act gets lazy with its storytelling. That is not even sure how to end the film. With one character going insane in the hospital and decides to face the slender man herself.

Overall, Slender Man is a bad film. It lacks scares and suspense. Characters make stupid decisions. Acting is boring. The direction is lazy and the script lacks in fleshing out their characters. Only good thing is Slender Man is kind of creepy.

review_title: What an Incredibly Underrated film, I truly don't understand the large amount of hate!
review_detailed_main: Provocative, engaging, and for the most part intelligent- Slender Man may fall short of a full conclusion, but makes up for it in its earlier content and direction. The film has its flaws, there is no doubt about that. The acting from some of the characters, namely Jaz Sinclair (and quite a few supporting actors), are quite obvious and corny. However, that isn't to say the film has terrible acting as a whole. Both Joey King and Julia Goldani Telles give their performances all they can throughout the film, and I would never think for a second they were bad in those roles. I thought they fit the film perfectly, both in acting, and in tone, and I felt they made the right casing choices for what the film needed. Annalise Basso also gives my favorite performance in the film, as short as it is, as her character feels incredibly grounded and focused every time she is on screen. The formula is a bit typical for this type of film, and can seem a bit predictable and/or tedious to watch. However, for the most part, the film is pretty interesting to watch. It's interesting to delve into the minds of these characters and see what the future has hold for them, and it's quite impressive what these actresses have in store for these roles. My biggest problem with the film is the ending, as it seems remarkably abrupt, and almost as if they didn't have time to edit it with any sort of real conclusion. It basically gives you all you need to keep going, but it still feels more like a glimpse of what the ending actually was going to be, than any sort of true conclusion. That all being said, I did enjoy the tone of the film very much, and found it to be incredibly atmospheric and quite nice to look at. The cinematography is very well done, and I surprisingly enjoyed the look ad interpretation of Slender Man throughout the film. In the end, Slender Man is not a great film by any means, but it certainly is an underappreciated gem in the horror world, and I urge those who haven't seen it to go in with an open mind if they ever do decide to watch it. My Rating: 7.5/10

review_title: Slender Man - Scary imagery, nothing else.
review_detailed_main:
Now, I have known about good ol' Slendy since about 2013-2014. Watched a lot of playthroughs, even two fan films. One slightly better than the other but both INFINITELY better than this boring, uninteresting, unimaginable, dark film. Oh, I don't mean the story, I mean the actual movie. What happened here? It is so dark that I had to squint my eyes several times. I also spent an entire day as it was so incredibly boring that I nearly fell asleep(I actually think I DID once) I mean, I like thematically dark movies but when the movie itself is so dark that you can't see, you did something wrong.

The movie is about this girl disappearing. Why? Slender Man. How? I dunno, there's no build-up in the slightest , it happens in broad daylight and NO ONE SEES HER DISAPPEAR! IN BROAD DAYLIGHT! SURROUNDED BY TEACHERS AND FRIENDS! J-just how? How I tell ya?

Now, is the story good? Well, no. It's a story. Long story short( HA!) The Slender Man movie is a compilation of "scary" images. There is no REAL story here, just a guy wanting to show his co-workers his film portfolio. Really, this looks like a demo-reel, a conceptual film about the character.

Oh, and how, you ask, does Slendy travel around? Apparently, by watching this rip-off Ringu( (The Ring) video on a website (Yeah, not Youtube, just a website) he comes around creepin' while you're sleepin', weirdly possessing the father of the girl to attack her friends. That's what I thought at first, but NOPE. He's just insane and nothing comes out of that: He breaks into the her friend's house, tries to kill them and gets arrested later that night. Yeah, and good ol' Slendy is in the living room in a scene, but it's so dark that I can't see him. I have to REWIND even though the sound is telling me to be scared.

Oh, and the ending? So confusing. I think.

In short, don't watch this unless you want a really good nap.

review_title: It only ends in insanity or death
Slender thin plot and characters: The Horror Movie Needs Some Tweaking
review_detailed_main:
Horror movies are flooding into the theater almost as fast comedies, and despite the mediocre reviews they continue to be churned out at the breakneck speed. Tonight, despite a Sci-Fi horror releasing this week, a second horror wants to take a stab at winning the box office battle. Robbie K here, bringing you another movie review to help guide your viewing pleasures. Let's get started as I share my opinions on:

Movie: Slenderman (2018)

Director: Sylvain White Writers: David Birke, Victor Surge (based on a character by) Stars: Joey King, Julia Goldani Telles, Jaz Sinclair

LIKES:

Short Run Time Good Cinematography Makeup/Visuals Design of Antagonist Okay Acting

Slenderman doesn't have much going for it for me, but at least the movie is at a short run time of about 80 minutes, so you don't have to put up with too long of a movie (assuming you stay for the whole show). The faster pace film has packs plenty of creepy-crawly mood to it, mostly thanks to the cinematography and setting designed for the movie. Bring in the makeup and visuals to further add that shadow of sadness/doom alongside the realistic setting and you an even strong case of being disturbed by the movie. Slenderman's various actions really can get under your skin, and once his form is solidly captured on set, you might get the final ambience of shivering in your skin as the CGI monster stalks the "heroines". As for the cast, they do well with the direction they were guided down, but I can't say more outside of that.

DISLIKES:

The Characters The Disturbing Imagery Plot Holes Chaotic Camera Work Aimless Direction

Unfortunately, the dislikes pile up, more so in how stereotypical this movie went forgoing any originality and potential for superficial gimmicks. The first aspect are the characters, very shallow teenagers who not only dug themselves a major hole in this film, but refusing to change. The static development leaves little to root for, nor any promise that things are going to go well for the teenage girls. Sadly, the girls primary growth occurs in their ability to tolerate the awful images the CGI ghost brings with him. Like the Ring, these visuals are not the most pleasing to watch and some felt unnecessary to include, thereby making their inclusion all the more pointless. Instead they should have worked on the story, for it had many plot holes and dead ends that were disappointing to say the least. Slenderman's avenues are quickly interrupted by prolonged bouts of cat and mouse games, where the camera work fails to capture all the details you wanted to see. In addition, the movie did not succeed in taking a firm direction, leading to this spiral of hodge-podge horror that left me bored, listless, and counting the minutes for this predictable film to end. I'll applaud the nods to other horror movies, but this piece meal needed some refining to bring Slenderman out to his full horror.

The Verdict:

Slenderman looked insane, and it delivered on that quite well in regards to the mental war it plays on the girls. Your scares come from realistic setting and camera work, but outside of that there is little to harp on. The movie's story is unfocussed, needing some editing and rewrites to really dive into the tale they wanted to present. In addition, deeper characters and better focus on the CGI villain is a must if the series is to survive. As such, I can't recommend this movie for theater, nor is it worth your time at most rental sites (unless you are a teen looking to test your merit). Given everything coming out save your money and target those movies in the near future.

My Scores:

Horror: 4.0 Movie Overall: 3.0-3.5

review_title: After reading opinions, you'll think this movie is a disaster. Oh well, it's not so bad.
review_detailed_main:
"Those who hear the three bells toll, accept his invitation. When you hear the first, you must close your eyes, keeping words unspoken. If one wants to hear, you must listen closely, for they are soft and distant."

I was really curious about this movie. Not that I expected anything spectacular. But the photos with this cult figure, which popped up on the internet, were rather intriguing. Not really scary but mysterious. A faceless figure with disproportionate limbs who appears in the background while observing children playing. A kind of Pied Piper of Hamelin who lures innocent children and makes them disappear. The fact this creation is the result of an internet competition is widely known. I was only curious if this figure would convince in a horror film. Well, it's not really innovative. You'll see the same clichés again. And the same stupidities and bad decisions are made by those who are about to become a victim. And the same tricks out of "Horror for dummies" are applied.

And yet, I didn't think it was bad. "Slender man" certainly isn't such a big fiasco as you might think. It isn't as disastrous as the comments you can read here and there on the internet. It won't go down in history as one of the most frightening or bloody horrors of all time. And the obscure and dark images creates an appropriate atmosphere but also ensure that you can't see a damn thing most of the time. But I felt that constant threat and the fear among the four teenage girls. And no, I won't have panic attacks immediately when hearing the sound of crackling wood. But these sound effects did create a creepy mood.

Normally I am such a person who whines about the fact that too little background information is given in a film. You are kept in the dark (appropriate for this movies) in terms of the origin and arising of the particular creepy phenomenon. With "Slender Man", however, I didn't think this was necessary. It made Slender Man even more mysterious. Summoning malicious demons also isn't exactly something new. Only recently you could see in "Pyewacket" how a frustrated teenage girl evoked something similar with the help of an occult ritual. And a long time ago, a group of young adults played a tape in "The Evil Dead" which caused Kandarian spirits to ruin everything. In "Slender Man" the cause of all the misery is a video on YouTube. Maybe that fits with today's time, but perhaps this bothered me the most. They tried to make it too hip. Especially when afterwards this ancient legend also knows about mobile phone technology.

Maybe that's the problem with this movie. They focused more on the continuation of the internet hype and tried to make a modern horror out of it. They lost sight of the concept of a well-thought-out horror. Maybe it fits perfectly with the life the four teenage girls Wren (Joey King), Hallie (Julia Goldani Telles), Chloe (Jaz Sinclair) and Katie (Annalize Basso) lead. A group of carefree teenagers who gained a certain popularity status at school (as seen in so many other Highschool films) and show an everyday affinity with current modern technology. They have more affection for their smartphone than for their fellow students. Yes, they display a kind of arrogance. To such an extent that they simply ignore the warnings for watching the video. Until one of them suddenly disappears and they realize that they might be stalked by this lugubrious figure.

Want to know my conclusion in the end? The whole legend created around this Slender Man was much more interesting than the film itself. All in all, it wasn't original and I didn't see anything baffling new in this film. But I still found certain scenes successful. Such as the one in the library with the use of a sort of psychedelic footage. And throughout the film, there are more of those hallucinatory passages. Also, I didn't think the acting was that awful. Ok, sometimes the four girls acted rather childish during meaningless conversations. And yes, some of their decisions were downright stupid. But that suited these young girls. And finally, I also thought the appearance of the mysterious Slender Man was reasonably successful. He blended perfectly with the background so you had this feeling that he could appear at any time. It's Javier Botet again who has put his peculiar physique at the service to play this nasty character. Just like he did in "Mama", "Don't knock twice" and "Mara". No, "Slender Man" wasn't disastrous, but seasoned horror fanatics will look at it in a rather condescending way. Beginners, on the other hand, might be afraid this faceless figure will show up. After all, they've seen a large part of the illustrious video. Not?

review_title: Creepy, but dumb. The Ring without Samora.

There is no background, there is no logic. What is slender man? Is he a shadow? Part tree? A tall skinny guy? Just accept that watching the video means you'll disappear or go crazy... yet again, all the teenagers in the world know about it, but no one else.

I have liked Joey King in the past, but she way overacted here. The girl who played Hallie did the best, but no one could save a plot that had more holes in it than a Vegas brothel.

review_title: Just made me wanna rewatch TribeTwelve. (Copied from myself with permission)
review_detailed_main:
For fanantics of the mythos and meme, Slender Man is too little too late. Slendy has been given mockumentary web shows (in addition to the awesome Marble Hornets) and plenty of fan films better than this supposed real deal, not to mention the popularity he was granted when an unfunny Let's Player screamed at some video games he was in. NOTE: One scene includes honest-to-God Deviantart images of the eponymous creature.

It isn't original or interesting as a film on its own, either. Its similarities with the Ringu series have been noted, and it fails to translate to film that which sounds intriguing when presented as a creepypasta; a purportedly legitimate blog accompanied by an ominous series of inexplicable YouTube clips. That close-to-home realism and, dare I say it, found-footage camera work is what made the mythos believable and effective. This film is visibly more expensive, stars obvious actors (bad ones), is shot like any other movie, and has an OST by the talented Ramin Djawadi, albeit asleep at the wheel with this one.

I don't mean to say that the Slender Man can't ever appear in a feature-length horror film with a budget. It's just that his is a story that works best when you read it in an email, see strange videos immediately afterwards, and soon begin to pay attention to noises from far away, as well as your own coughs. If you want to make a full-on movie about him - especially years after the Slendy ship has sailed and people are more horrified by American politics than forest-dwelling monsters that cause space-time disruptions and insanity - you'll want to make something less derivative, poorly acted, unironically formulaic and bland than Slender Man.

This audio-visual product is just a series of scenes and shots tied together by ... a ... dude without a face who makes hallucinate for some reason. No relation to the horror walking simulator.

This product was not even ironically entertaining. Just ignore the existence of it.

review_title: Worse than the reviews led me to believe!
review_detailed_main:
I started watching this movie with low expectations. I loved the Slenderman games and find them incredibly unnerving to play (particularly alone in the dark with headphones on) and when I heard this movie was being made I was certainly intrigued. I mean this is such a mysterious character. That means that the movie has unlimited options in terms of what sort of story to tell. However, once the trailer was released I knew what we were getting: a movie that is weird for the sake of being weird. But...as a fan of the games (and someone with too much time on their hands due to the recent development of insomnia) I decided to give it a watch. I checked IMDB beforehand just to see how it was being rated. 3.1! I've NEVER seen a movie being rated so poorly. But, the comments were fairly positive. In fact, many of them claimed they didn't understand why the movie was receiving so much hate. I'll tell you why: 1. The story is one of the most poorly written stories I've ever had the misfortune of experiencing. From the moment the movie starts, every single character is a cliche. Somehow, they manage to all be cliches and yet are still entirely underdeveloped. The character development is little to none and any character development that does take place is done through the characters themselves actually saying it. 2. The sound effects used in this movie are supposed to resemble the game (I assume) but they happen at random times, they don't sound creepy, and worst of all, you can see that the creators were under the impression that cheap-sounding special effects would help set the tone...they don't. 3. Without giving away any spoilers, you can actually see, moment by moment, all the other movies that this one took inspiration from (I say inspiration but it is closer to plagiarism.

All in all, rather than leaving me scared or unnerved, this movie has actually managed to make Slenderman seem less like a horror characters and more like a spoof of one. If you'd added some jokes here and there, this movie could easily have been considered a horror movie spoof because it's THAT far away from being scary!

In 2018 Wisconsin, four teenage girls learn about the "sensation" that is Slender Man, the supernatural, faceless demon that steals children and haunts you nonstop. Via typical horror movie clichés, they watch the video (depicted in a similar manner to The Ring) and proceed to have their oh so ordinary lives upturned after one of them disappears.

Either because this meme actually (most famously) inspired foolish pre-teens to try and appease the entity by attempting to kill a classmate or it's just outdated, this thing that calls itself a movie is one extended eye roll that's surely to end up in the 99¢ bin at your local convenience store. 0.5/5.

REVIEW - SLENDER MAN

UK release date 24 August 18

What started out as a meme in 2009 in an online forum to create a scary character has developed into an Urban Myth, various games and now a film.

There have been a few fan films made but this is the long overdue film which fans of the Slender Man character have been waiting for, but was it worth the wait?

I am afraid not, not by a long shot which is such a shame because the Urban Myth, character and subsequent games could have ensured a massive audience but with its simple yet predictable story this isn't even scary in the slightest, yes better than the extremely silly Hereditary.

In my personal opinion the film is just wrong and could have been far better, take the Urban Myth about Candy man (I dare you to say Candy Man 3 times) which actually acknowledged the Urban Myth or was it, this film from the start takes more 'its real' path and is let down because of it.

I will put it to you, what is more scary, an Urban Myth that could be true or an Urban Myth that is ignored and made out to be real? One could be in the real world and the other you know isn't. This is the underlying reason why Slender Man has been so popular but the film will spoil the whole Urban Myth surrounding Slender Man and not add to it, which is an opportunity lost.

Rating 3 out of 10

review_title: NOT worth the money or time to go see
review_detailed_main: Honestly the worst scary movie I've ever watched. Hearing stories about the legend of Slender Man, four girls watch a video which will supposedly summon him. Although following precisely the instructions from the clip, the girls say that everything is nonsense, but when the suddenly begin to have nightmares about the creature and one of them goes missing, their sanity and also friendship will be put to the test.

It's a supposedly horror movie which introduces the legend of Slender Man and how four girls get involved in his stories. I say supposedly because it almost not scary at all. It bases solely on jump-scares, a cheap tactic which makes the viewer startle, but without a truly scary atmosphere or creature which can generate this type of emotion. Speaking of the atmosphere, it is mostly dull, lacking suspense, drama or any sense of empathy towards the characters, making the whole action truly pointless.

The plot is simply stupid. It bases its entire action on the summoning of a mystical creature, which is also as dumb as it gets, which will do what it does best to take care of the main characters, one by one. You get no drama, no suspense, no emotion... just pure linearity and also predictability. The characters are very simple, not well developed, acting strange and making irrational decisions in key moments, eliminating any chance of caring for their fate. It's almost laughable when you see how they react in different situations; that's how bad they are.

In order to describe the creature, the movie uses some "special" effects which are sometimes so bad that they seem to be made in a coffee break using last century's technology. You can only imagine how disappointing or even laughable this can get, when judging the fact that they should induce fear or at least drama. Another aspect which is to be mentioned is the finale. I honestly expected it to bring something different, something that might make the previous hour and a half a bit less pointless. Unfortunately, as with the rest of the film, it fails miserably do deliver anything out of the ordinary, ending suddenly and almost without any clue.

As you might have guessed by now, this movie is a disaster. It isn't able to be what it was supposed to be, a horror movie, it fails to deliver a decent story or characters and it really fails to generate fear, drama, suspense or anything like these, except a couple of cheap jump-scares. It's a truly awful movie which should be avoided at any cost.

Slender Man is a movie one ends up watching just to satisfy a morbid curiosity. It's obvious to anybody who has visited online horror forums before that nothing good is gonna come out of a major motion picture based in an internet creepypasta. The source material is not elaborate or cohesive enough to justify making a full-length film about it, unless the writers are able to expand on it and fix it, which is not the case here.

Since there's so little backstory behind this creature, the plot is very straightforward and a little uneventful. Four friends decide to summon the entity known as Slender Man out of boredom during a sleepover. At first, they don't take the consequences of their actions seriously, until, after a while, one of them disappears. Not much else happens. However, part of the narrative feels disconnected from the bigger scheme, because some minor events are left without resolution.

The characters are basically non-existent, with only slight hints of what could pass as a personality for each one. The consequence is the audience's complete indifference to what will happen to them, limiting the interest in watching this film to an occasional jump scare or possible gory outcome to a particular scene. The actors do what they can with the material they're given, but the result is mediocre at best.

The awful CGI is distracting, though there's not a lot more they could have done here. The biggest problem is the concept behind the story, too broad to be scary. It negatively affects the cinematography that follows the same generic path. There is one or two interesting images that would form nice compositions if they were part of a collage in an art exhibit, but here they're just not very special.

If anything, the biggest flaw in this film is taking itself too seriously. It misses the opportunity to have fun with its own stupidity, and prevents the audience to do the same. Therefore, there is no reason to watch it. Skip it.

review_title: Could of be good. It really wasn't.
review_detailed_main: I don't often write reviews but I'm compelled to write one this time. The slender man legend has always been an interesting premise for me so when I heard a film was coming I was excited. It came out in the cinema and got shocking reviews so I waited for home release. I wish I hadn't bothered. It looked good, in places. But the main thing was you saw him too much. The point in slender man is that you barely see him or just glimpses. It wasn't scary at all, no jump scares either. You can tell it had been cut to pieces to get a lower age rating and in places it didn't make sense because of it. The acting wasn't too bad but the script was badly written also. It was so cliche in places you wanted to throw things at the tv and scream why would you do that it's 2018!! The pace was slow in places for a "horror film" and it just seemed so bland. It trails along from bad to good effects then bad again. Parts of it looked creepy to start of with then looked silly. It could of been so good. It's great source material and if someone like James Wan had the directors chair I think it could of been something special. However I struggled to finish it but did and didn't really care about any of the characters because to be honest parts of it just didn't make sense. A waste of a perfectly good premise. Avoid if you like decent horror. I would say try the Nun this year but that also was pretty poor considering it was a conjuring spin off. Please someone try again and make a good movie of it.

review_title: An okay chiller that could have done with being more disturbing
review_detailed_main:
A quartet of Massachusetts high school girls have read about the eponymous Slender Man, a tall faceless individual who abducts youngsters or drives them insane, and decide to perform a ritual to summon him. Not long afterwards one of them disappears. The others believe there is a way to get her back and head into the woods to summon the Slender Man once more... somewhat inevitably this doesn't work and soon they are haunted by visions of him. Will any of them survive?

I thought this was okay... but it could have been so much better. On the positive side there was a good creepy atmosphere, the effects were okay and the acting wasn't bad. On the downside it felt far too anaemic, as though the makers sacrificed the chance of making it really scary or showing any gore or unpleasantness to get a more child-friendly rating. There are also quite a few genre clichés that are overused such as dreams within dreams, lots of screaming and false scares. Overall I'd say this was decent enough for something I watched on Netflix; I was just left a bit disappointed as I felt the ideas were good and could have made a great horror film... perhaps it will one day.

The story behind the movie was good but the cgi, acting, and cameras was bad. I thought it needed more horror scenes and the directors should have put more time into this movie.

"Slender Man" is a Mystery - Horror movie in which we watch a group of teenage girls who are fascinated by the internet lore of the Slender Man, attempt to prove that he doesn't actually exist by summoning him with a ritual. After the ritual, each one of them started to experience some supernatural phenomena that make them believe that the story is real. Everything changes when one of them mysteriously goes missing and the others start to worry not only for her but also for themselves.

I have to admit that I have high hopes for this movie and I was really disappointed by it. The plot was awful and had many plot holes and a script that could not cover them not even a bit. The cast made below average interpretations that made the audience not able to understand their feelings and what they have been through at these moments of terror. I did not like the interpretations of Joey King who played as Wren and Julia Goldani Telles who played as Hallie, and I have to say that I expected more from Annalise Basso who played as Katie because I believe that she did not reach her potential. The direction which was made by Sylvain White was average and some suspense moments - scenes were not enough.

To sum up, I believe that "Slender Man" is an awful movie with a bad plot and poor direction. I do not recommend anyone to watch it but if you are curious about it and you want to watch just do not have high hopes for it because I am sure that you are going to be disappointed by it.

review_title: I've never written a review. This movie left me no choice.
A film with a lot of potential that could have been more than just a commercial film
review_detailed_main:
Slender Man was a very popular figure along with Jeff The Killer when Creepypastas had become a phenomenon on the Internet, giving rise to new urban legends for the digital generation. A movie about Slender Man was a good idea for this phenomenon and could have taken Creepypasta's fame to another level. Since they began making films focused on social networks, it is clear that internet culture has gained so much relevance that they wanted to take it beyond its borders through cinematographic art. Sony tried to do that with The Emoji Movie and the result was not pleasant for much of the audience. A year later, Sony decided to try again with a Slender Man movie and it ended up being a second setback. The only good thing is that both did not do very badly at the box office and with the arrival of the Wattpad movies and the Five Nights At Freddy's movie, the financial success they have received has made internet culture as relevant as the film producers wanted so much regardless of the bad reviews.

The Slender Man movie has been quite divisive due to the changes that were made when it was originally going to be rated R, but the negative reaction to the first trailer caused that to be changed causing the movie to end up being rated PG13 and being removed. Some scenes from the first trailer. The film may not have been liked by Slender Man fans due to the changes that were made to the final result, but there are fans who were satisfied and others were able to at least get to know Creepypasta through this film. Although it may not seem like it, the film does have positive things. It must be taken into account that Slender Man does not have a fixed canon and Internet users spread the legend with a lot of material that they themselves have created without having altered the main concept. What characterizes Slender Man quite a bit is that he usually captures children like Boogeyman and the film further expands that concept by suggesting that he can kidnap teenagers. The reality is that teenagers are not fully adults and are still children who are just going through the transition from child to adult. In addition, teenagers depend quite a bit on social networks and they are part of the audience that has expanded the legend of Slender Man. So involving teenagers in the film is justifiable, although involving children would have helped a lot.

Also, the movie is only based on the character and not on the Creepypasta itself, so what the movie presents is an interpretation of the character according to the lore. The film is partly faithful to the character's lore because it maintains that mystery and suspense that characterizes Slender Man and takes into account the influence that it has generated so that it ended up going viral all over the Internet. The nightmare-like scenes and the scenes where the girls are stalked by Slender Man clearly look like they were taken from the characters' video games. What the film offers is a kind of mix of Ringu and A Nightmare On Elm Street offering dark sequences that fit the character very well. The soundtrack and sound effects manage to create a good atmosphere of tension. The CGI is not very good, but at least they respected the appearance of Slender Man and offered good sequences in which you can feel the air of Slender Man. What is true is that Internet users have expanded the Slender myth so much Well there is a lot of material that could have been included.

The movie certainly had more room to add more material and further develop the Slender Man mythology. 2 hours and 30 minutes or even just 2 hours would have been enough for the movie to develop Slender Man more. Sony certainly wasn't going to do That's because the film was not going to be completely commercial and I was already worried after the first bad reactions. There is no denying that this film had a lot of potential, but the real problem is the script and direction it had. It must be admitted that the movie Always Watching is better because despite being a found footage movie, it knew how to handle the Slender Man myth with more subtlety and take advantage of the feeling of tension generated by the character. On the other hand, this film focused more on being a commercial film and that is why it falls into being just another movie in the bunch. Because some scenes were cut, you can tell that more of the movie is missing because there are moments where some situations are skipped. Katie's disappearance happens out of nowhere without giving much context and something similar happens with Wren, who disappears from the film without any explanation and becomes a loose end. There are several things in the film that are left unresolved or unexplained. There is still the question of who the mysterious user the girls were contacting was. Most likely, all the doubts that the film leaves would have been answered in a sequel that never came in the end. The script really has plot holes that needed to be filled. The girls in this movie are the same thing that has been seen several times in horror movies. They make bad decisions when they are so blinded by panic and desperation.

So the disappointment of many Slender Man fans is understandable because this movie could have been something great, but it ended up being another simple commercial horror movie about teenagers being chased by a monster. Maybe with another screenwriter or another director it would have been different. In the end, Slender Man: The Movie is not the worst thing ever made as many say, but it is a film that does not contribute much to the popularity of Creepypasta. It is a film that only serves to entertain and it does not fail in that. It's a movie that can be enjoyed one night in the afternoon, but that's all it has to offer. My final rating for this movie is a 6/10.

review_title: Mostly Boring, Plus a Few Laughs
review_detailed_main:
Slender Man will surely go down as one of the worst movies of the year. As the title of this review indicates, it is mostly a boring, nonsensical series of events saved from a lower rating by a few scenes in which it crosses into "so bad it's good" territory.

Although the acting and visuals are both terrible, the writing is probably the weakest aspect of Slender Man. Most of the plot involves characters doing the same things over and over again. Various "scary" set-ups are reused multiple times. Characters utter awkward, wooden lines at inappropriate times. Together, these constitute about 90% of the runtime.

The remaining 10% of the movie is where things get funny. A few scenes, which are concentrated in the middle-to-late portions of the film, go completely off the rails. In one, a wildly underdeveloped character's face morphs into a caricature while speaking normally. In another, the staff of a hospital turn into automatons. People openly laughed in the theater. These funny scenes elevate the movie from a 2 to a 3.
The scariest part about this was that I had to spend $5 to go see it.
